metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: Python Booleans
Booleans represent one of two values: True or False .
content.html: Booleans represent one of two values: True or False.

content.text: Boolean Values
In programming you often need to know if an expression is True or False .
content.html: In programming you often need to know if an expression is True or False.

content.text: You can evaluate any expression in Python, and get one of two answers, True or False .
content.html: You can evaluate any expression in Python, and get one of two answers, True or False.

content.text: When you compare two values, the expression is evaluated and Python returns the Boolean answer:
content.html: When you compare two values, the expression is evaluated and Python returns the Boolean answer:

content.code_html:
print(10 > 9)
print(10 == 9)
print(10 < 9)

content.text: When you run a condition in an if statement, Python returns True or False :
content.html: When you run a condition in an if statement, Python returns True or False:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
a = 200b = 33if b > a:  print("b is greater than a")
  else:  print("b is not greater than a")

content.code:
a = 200b = 33if b > a:  print("b is greater than a")
else:  print("b is not greater than a")

syntax_highlighting.text:
a = 200b = 33if b > a:  print("b is greater than a")
 else:  print("b is not greater than a")

content.code_html:
a = 200
b = 33

if b > a:
  print("b is greater than a")
else:
  print("b is not greater than a")

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
a = 200b = 33if b > a:  print("b is greater than a")
  else:  print("b is not greater than a")

content.text: Evaluate Values and Variables
The bool() function allows you to evaluate any value, and give you True or False in return,
content.html: The bool() function allows you to evaluate any value, and give you True or False in return,

content.code_html:
print(bool("Hello"))
print(bool(15))

x = "Hello"
y = 15

print(bool(x))
print(bool(y))

content.text: Most Values are True
Almost any value is evaluated to True if it has some sort of content.
content.html: Almost any value is evaluated to True if it has some sort of content.

content.text: Any string is True , except empty strings.
Any number is True , except 0 .
Any list, tuple, set, and dictionary are True , except empty ones.
content.html: Any list, tuple, set, and dictionary are True, except empty ones.

content.code_html:
bool("abc")
bool(123)
bool(["apple", "cherry", "banana"])

content.text: Some Values are False
In fact, there are not many values that evaluate to False , except empty values, such as () , [] , {} , "" , the number 0 , and the value None . And of course the value False evaluates to False .
content.html: In fact, there are not many values that evaluate to False, except empty values, such as (), [], {}, "", the number 0, and the value None. And of course the value False evaluates to False.

content.code_html:
bool(False)
bool(None)
bool(0)
bool("")
bool(())
bool([])
bool({})

content.text: One more value, or object in this case, evaluates to False , and that is if you have an object that is made from a class with a __len__ function that returns 0 or False :
content.html: One more value, or object in this case, evaluates to False, and that is if you have an object that is made from a class with a __len__ function that returns 0 or False:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
class myclass():  def __len__(self):    return 0
  myobj = myclass()print(bool(myobj))

content.code:
class myclass():  def __len__(self):    return 0
myobj = myclass()print(bool(myobj))

syntax_highlighting.text:
class myclass():  def __len__(self):    return 0
 myobj = myclass()print(bool(myobj))

content.code_html:
class myclass():
  def __len__(self):
    return 0

myobj = myclass()
print(bool(myobj))

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
class myclass():  def __len__(self):    return 0
  myobj = myclass()print(bool(myobj))

content.text: Functions can Return a Boolean
You can create functions that returns a Boolean Value:
content.html: You can create functions that returns a Boolean Value:

content.code_html:
def myFunction() :
  return True

print(myFunction())

content.text: You can execute code based on the Boolean answer of a function:
content.html: You can execute code based on the Boolean answer of a function:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
def myFunction() :  return Trueif myFunction():  
  print("YES!")else:  print("NO!")

content.code:
def myFunction() :  return Trueif myFunction():
print("YES!")else:  print("NO!")

syntax_highlighting.text:
def myFunction() :  return Trueif myFunction():  
 print("YES!")else:  print("NO!")

content.code_html:
def myFunction() :
  return True

if myFunction():
  print("YES!")
else:
  print("NO!")

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
def myFunction() :  return Trueif myFunction():  
  print("YES!")else:  print("NO!")

content.text: Python also has many built-in functions that return a boolean value, like the isinstance() function, which can be used to determine if an object is of a certain data type:
content.html: Python also has many built-in functions that return a boolean value, like the isinstance() function, which can be used to determine if an object is of a certain data type:

content.code_html:
x = 200
print(isinstance(x, int))

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
What will be the result of the following syntax: print(5 > 3) ?
content.html:
What will be the result of the following syntax:
print(5 > 3)?
